problem: Two intersecting circles have a common chord of length 16 ft, and their centers lie on opposite sides of the chord. The radii of the circles are 10 ft and 17 ft respectively. Express the distance between the centers of the circles in feet.
model_solution:
Draw a diagram.
Let the centers of the circles be A and B, and the point of intersection of the circles be C. Draw the radii AC and BC, and the altitude from C to AB.
Drop a perpendicular from A to the chord, and call the foot of the perpendicular D.
Find the length of AD by using the Pythagorean Theorem on triangle ACD.
Drop a perpendicular from B to the chord, and call the foot of the perpendicular E. Find the length of BE by using the Pythagorean Theorem on triangle BCE.
Drop a perpendicular from C to AB, and call the foot of the perpendicular F. In triangles AFD and BFC, the altitude is common and the other two sides are radii, so they are congruent, and AD = BE.
Use the Pythagorean Theorem on triangle ADF to find the length of AF, and then find the length of AB.
